title: 【#賴日福 被刑拘 曾發「願榮光歸香港」視頻】

replies.msg:
賴日福（網名花滿樓）昨晚與7歲兒子回廣州家中期間被抓捕，家屬今天晚上（9月16日）收到刑拘通知書，指頼日福涉嫌尋釁滋事被捕。賴日福孩子昨日目睹父親被不明男子撲倒在地帶走，後被獨留在家，受嚇過度整夜啼哭，十分擔心父親安危。

賴日福於上週五曾在微信朋友圈及臉書上載一段影片，配樂是願榮光歸香港，拍攝的是他家鄕附近河山，並配文「這是我的祖國，我要讓她自由！」當局近日大舉掃蕩網絡言論，特別針對涉港發言，賴日福疑因此被盯上。他於本年4月就曾因穿著公民抗命丅恤，疑似聲援佔中九子被行政拘留。到8月反送中運動爆發後，他曾被迫㝍下保證書，保證10月10日前不去香港旅遊、購物以及參與活動，同時保證不在網上發佈涉政敏感性言論。

賴日福是 #南方街頭運動 成員，因參與抗爭行動多次被拘留。南方街頭運動的三名成員曾因聲援雨傘運動被判刑4年至4年半，近日才出獄。

【Lai Rifu has been criminally detained
Suspected to be related to his video post of 「Glory to Hong Kong」】

Lai Rifu (online alias Hua Manlou) was arrested last night when he was on his way home together with his seven years old son in Guangzhou. His family received a Notice of Criminal Detention this evening (16 September 2019), which stated that Lai was suspected of picking quarrels and provoking troubles. Lai’s young son witnessed the brutal arrest of his father first handed, watching him being pushed to the ground by a gang of unknown men, then was left behind alone at home. The child was traumatized and cried all night, worried sick about his father.

Lai uploaded a video last Friday to his Wechat Moment and Facebook account, which has the background music 「Glory to Hong Kong」. The video shows scenery near his home town, and was posted with the caption 「This is my homeland, I want her to be free!」. The Chinese authorities is having a widespread crackdown on internet speech in recent days, specifically targeting Hong Kong related speech, and it is suspected that Lai was hence targeted. Lai was administratively detained in April this year for wearing a T-shirt with the words 「civil disobedience」; coupled with the timing near the trial of the Occupy Central Nine, his action was interpreted to be in support of the nine Hong Kong activists. In August after the eruption of the Anti-Extradiction Bill protests, Lai was forced to write a statement, promising that he would not go to Hong Kong before 10 October for tourism, shopping or other activities, and also that he would not posted sensitive speech online.

Lai is a long time member of the Southern Street Movement, and has been repeatedly detained for his activism. Three other members of the Southern Street Movement had been previously sentenced to four to four and a half years imprisonment for supporting the Umbrella Movement in 2014, and were only released recently.
